custom_fields.key_topics: digital humanities, digital history, cultural analytics, digital literary studies, library science, basic programming
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should either come with experience studying and writing about humanities subjects, or experience employing technical, statistical, or design approaches to create things or solve problems. All students should be interested in the cultural world around them.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
"Wreading" Exercises


You will be responsible for three short, ungraded essays ("wreading" assignments) over the course of the semester. These assignments are low-stakes and are intended to facilitate creative and engaged thinking about the readings. You will distribute your wreading exercises to the class, and they will provide a jumping-off point for class discussions.



Project Proposal


About a third of the way through the semester, you will be responsible for a project proposal with two components, (a.) an in-class presentation to the class "pitching" classmates on your idea; (b.) a 4-5 page written description of the project detailing the rationale, proposed outcomes, data sources, known challenges, and proposed workarounds.



Final Projects


Following the project proposals, class members will choose 3 or so of the proposed projects to develop collaboratively over the remainder of the semester. Final projects may be in the form of a website, a dataset, a film, an essay, or any combination of the above.
custom_fields.goals: Students will be able to use computers more effectively for their research collaborate more effectively with diverse communities add new skills and programming packages to their CVs
custom_fields.relevance:
Students will be able to:

* use computers more effectively for their research


* collaborate more effectively with diverse communities


* add new skills and programming packages to their CVs
custom_fields.learning_resources: potential partnership to with National Humanities Alliance

long_desc: This course is a learn by doing introduction to questions and methods in digital humanities, with special emphases on common tasks in digital history, digital literary studies, library science, and cultural analytics. Students will likely partner with a national humanities organization to tackle realworld humanities problems while developing core computational competencies such as those required for gathering data text mining, APIs, transforming data OCR, regular expressions, natural language processing, image magick, file management shell commands, data visualization matplotlib, arcGIS, and more.

prereqs.text: (76-101 at least D) or (76-102 at least D) or ((76-106 at least D) and (76-107 at least D)) or ((76-106 at least D) and (76-108 at least D)) or ((76-107 at least D) and (76-108 at least D))
